Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant for a Utilities and Energy Regional Center of Excellence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This planning grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Utilities and Energy Regional Center of Excellence. To accomplish this goal, the project team is focused on three objectives: 1: Develop a robust network of industry and educational partners; 2. Investigate and document the utilities and energy education needs in the Midwest; and 3. Develop a plan to increase the availability of utilities training for technicians.

This project has the potential to advance knowledge in the utilities and energy sectors, particularly at the two-year college level. As new workers replace retiring workers, the industry will have an influx of newly trained employees, some of whom might not have much hands-on experience. This planning grant will work with partners across the Midwest, including some of the Midwest's largest energy companies, to ensure that graduates have the skills required to keep the energy companies running. Leveraging resources across colleges and state boundaries, whether they be state-of-the-art laboratories or industry expertise, can help multiple colleges work together to create more options for cost-effective utilities and energy programming.

Increasing the diversity of those who participate in energy careers with be crucial to the health of these industries. Changing the demographic makeup of the workforce needs to begin at the two-year college level. For this reason, this planning grant will gather demographic information and best practices and use a planning summit to develop a strategy for broadening participation by the end of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Planning Grant for a Utilities and Energy Regional Center of Excellence project was designed with the goal of developing well-formulated plans for a future Utilities and Energy Regional Center of Excellence. To accomplish this goal, the project team focused on three objectives:1) Developing a robust network of industry and educational partners; 2) Investigating and documenting the utilities and energy education needs in the Midwest; and 3) Developing a plan to increase the availability of utilities training for technicians. Project activities included: attending conferences to develop and strengthen relationships with industry/employers, visiting the Midwest Photonics Education Center to learn more about how they are combining hands-on training with virtual courses, and using information gathered and industry focus group results from the Utilities Pipeline Development for Advanced Technical Education (i.e. NSF Award No. 1304726) to determine that the best path forward to increase the number of skilled technicians in the utility and energy workforce.  An Energy Center of Excellence would provide a resource for colleges and workforce entities throughout the country to gain knowledge to create or improve utility and energy education programs.

Intellectual Merit. This project helped the College advance its knowledge in the utilities and energy sectors, particularly at the two-year college level. As new workers replace retiring workers, the industry will have an influx of newly trained employees, some of whom might not have much hands-on experience. This planning grant worked with partners across the Midwest, including some of the Midwest?s largest energy companies, to ensure that graduates have the skills required to keep the energy companies running. Leveraging resources across colleges and state boundaries, whether they be state-of-the-art laboratories or industry expertise, has the potential to help multiple colleges work together to create more options for cost-effective utilities and energy programming.  

 Broader Impacts. Increasing the diversity of those who participate in energy careers with be crucial to the health of these industries. The Center for Energy Workforce Development (CEWD), for example, focuses on five key demographics: youth, low income young adults, women, military and transitioning workers. Changing the demographic makeup of the workforce needs to begin at the two-year college level. For this reason, this planning grant gathered demographic information and best practices and used a focus group to determine what the critical competencies for the industry are and create agreement amongst the large employers.  This agreement on key competencies and program courses allows employers in various parts of the country to know the skills of the graduates they plan to hire and offers a more tailored approach to on the job training.  New employees are able to be productive members of the companies quicker.  In addition, this project was mindful that all voices needed to be included in the planning grant and made efforts to reach out to rural areas that are served by small utility companies, such as cooperatives, municipals and investor owned companies.
